```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
```

## Libraries

I am going to use the following libraries:

```{r libraries}
library(tidyverse)
library(giscoR) # for maps
library(dataregacc) # available with remotes::install_github("Luisbia/dataregacc")
library(showtext) # for font
library(data.table)
```

## Data for the map

We get the geographical information from the regions with `{giscoR}`

```{r giscoR}
# get EU27 country codes
eu2021 <- gisco_countrycode[gisco_countrycode$eu, ]$CNTR_CODE 

# get NUTS 2 geometry
nuts2 <- gisco_get_nuts(
  year = "2021",
  epsg = "3035",
  resolution = "3",
  nuts_level = "2",
  country = eu2021
)

# get borders
borders <- gisco_get_nuts(
  epsg = "3035",
  year = "2021",
  resolution = "3",
  country = eu2021,
  nuts_level = "2"
)
```

And the data from `{dataregacc}`.

```{r data}
data<- regacc %>% 
  filter(table =="2gdp" &
         time == 2020 &
         NUTS == 2 &
         unit == "PPS_HAB_EU27_2020") %>% 
  select(geo, values)
```

## Merge data and geometry

We merge the data with the geometry.

```{r merge}
nuts2.sf <- merge(nuts2,
                  data,
                  by.x = "NUTS_ID",
                  by.y = "geo",
                  all.x = TRUE
)
```

## Defining the classes

It might be helpful to define the classes of the map  using the `quantile` function.

```{r}
# Breaks
classes <- data %>% 
  pull(values) %>% 
  quantile(probs = seq(0, 1, 1/10),na.rm = TRUE)

classes
```

We create the breaks.

```{r breaks}
br <- c(29.9,53,63,70,80,90,100,105,120,140,275)
```

and apply them to the data.

```{r classes}
# Cut
nuts2.sf$values_groups <- cut(nuts2.sf$values, breaks = br)
```

## Creating the labels

And the labels for them. We create a custom text for the first and last one.

```{r labels}
# Labels
labels <- br
labels[1] <- "<53"
labels[10] <- ">140"
```

## Colours

We choose a palette.

```{r palette}
# Plot
pal <- hcl.colors(length(br), "Spectral")
```

## Final chart

Finally, we create the chart...very much following a template developed by  Milos Popovic: <https://milospopovic.net/how-to-make-choropleth-map-in-r/>.

```{r map, fig.height=12, fig.width=9}
map<- ggplot(nuts2.sf) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = values_groups), color = NA, alpha = 0.9) +
  geom_sf(data = borders, fill = NA, size = 0.05, color = "black") +
  # Center in Europe: EPSG 3035
  coord_sf(
    xlim = c(2377294, 6500000),
    ylim = c(1413597, 5228510)
  )+
  labs(
    title = "GDP per capita in PPS, 2020",
    subtitle = "As % of EU average",
    caption = paste0(
      "Source: Luis Biedma, Eurostat\n ", gisco_attributions()
    )
  )+
  scale_fill_manual(
    name = "EU=100",
    values = pal,
    drop = FALSE,
    na.value = "grey",
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide_legend(
      direction = "horizontal",
      keyheight = 0.5,
      keywidth = 2,
      title.position = "top",
      title.hjust = 0,
      label.hjust = .5,
      nrow = 1,
      byrow = TRUE,
      reverse = FALSE,
      label.position = "bottom"
    )
  )+
  theme_void() +
  # Theme
  theme(
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.title = element_text(
      color = "black",
      hjust = 0.5,
      vjust = -1,
    ),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(
      color = "black",
      hjust = 0.5,
      vjust = -2,
      face = "bold"
    ),
    plot.caption = element_text(
      color = "black",
      size = 6,
      hjust = 0.5,
      margin = margin(b = 2, t = 13)
    ),
    legend.text = element_text(
      size = 7,
      color = "black"
    ),
    legend.title = element_text(
      size = 7,
      color = "black"
    ),
    legend.position = c(0.5, 0.02)
  )

map
```
